content: 1,400 jobs axed as Reitmans shutters all Addition Elle and Thyme Maternity stores | BramptonGuardian.com 1,400 jobs axed as Reitmans shutters all Addition Elle and Thyme Maternity stores News Jun 02, 2020 by Marta Marychuk Brampton Guardian Reitmans announced June 2 it will close all 77 Addition Elle and 54 Thyme Maternity stores in Canada this summer as the company restructures. As a result of this decision, Reitmans plans to restructure all teams within the company, and will be reducing its workforce by approximately 1,100 employees in retail stores and approximately 300 employees at its head office in Montreal. The Montreal-based retailer of ladies’ fashion announced in May that it was seeking creditor protection under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act while it implements a restructuring plan that addresses the impacts of COVID-19. The company plans to focus on three brands: Reitmans, Penningtons and RW & CO. In the coming weeks, all Reitmans stores will continue to reopen based on government guidelines, including all Addition Elle and Thyme Maternity stores. In Mississauga, there are Thyme Maternity and Addition Elle stores at the Heartland Town Centre. In Brampton, there is a Thyme Maternity store at the Bramalea City Centre and an Addition Elle store at the Trinity Common Square. For these two brands, the objective will be to liquidate the inventory in anticipation of their permanent closure, which is planned for July 18, 2020 for Thyme Maternity, and Aug. 15, 2020 for Addition Elle. Their respective e-commerce websites are expected to shut down on the same date as the closure of the brick-and-mortar stores. 1,400 jobs axed as Reitmans shutters all Addition Elle and Thyme Maternity stores Stores in Brampton, Caledon and Mississauga impacted News Jun 02, 2020 by Marta Marychuk Brampton Guardian Reitmans announced June 2 it will close all 77 Addition Elle and 54 Thyme Maternity stores in Canada this summer as the company restructures. The Montreal-based retailer of ladies’ fashion announced in May that it was seeking creditor protection under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act while it implements a restructuring plan that addresses the impacts of COVID-19. The company plans to focus on three brands: Reitmans, Penningtons and RW & CO. In the coming weeks, all Reitmans stores will continue to reopen based on government guidelines, including all Addition Elle and Thyme Maternity stores. Their respective e-commerce websites are expected to shut down on the same date as the closure of the brick-and-mortar stores. UPDATE: Three Brampton correctional officers test positive for coronavirus | BramptonGuardian.com UPDATE: Three Brampton correctional officers test positive for coronavirus News Apr 16, 2020 by Sabrina Gamrot Brampton Guardian The Brampton Correctional Institute is the latest building in the city to report confirmed cases of COVID-19. Peel Public Health has confirmed the outbreak, which is declared when two or more cases of COVID-19 are detected in a facility. Public Health has launched an investigation into the outbreak, according to Peel Medical Officer of Health, Dr. Lawrence Loh. He also confirmed that the disease was not spread by institutional exposure but by community spread and close contact. Several inmates who are showing signs of COVID-19 are now in isolation and their test results have been put in as a "rushed order," according to Loh. Co-workers who were in contact with the three officers are being contacted by public health. Public Health is now helping the facility implement safety measures to help control the infection. The Office of the Solicitor General provided this statement; "The ministry wishes staff a speedy recovery and out of respect for their health privacy it would be inappropriate to provide further specifics.The ministry is working closely with Peel Public Health and continues to take guidance from them on how best to proceed. The ministry has taken steps at OCI to prevent the spread of COVID-19, and implement measures through the institutional pandemic plan." Brampton Mayor Patrick Brown originally confirmed the outbreak early Thursday morning after being briefed by Loh. Brampton’s correctional institute is located at 109 McLaughlin Rd. and has a capacity to hold 228 inmates. According to Info Peel, the centre is used for minimum periods of incarceration and rehabilitation. **Editor's Note: The story was updated at 4:46 p.m. on Thursday, April 16 to include more information from Dr. Lawrence Loh and a statement from the Solicitor General's office. Maple Leaf Foods reports two more coronavirus cases out of Brampton facility | BramptonGuardian.com Maple Leaf Foods reports two more coronavirus cases out of Brampton facility News Apr 14, 2020 by Iain Colpitts Brampton Guardian Maple Leaf Foods has reported two more employees out of its Brampton poultry plant tested positive for coronavirus on Monday, April 13. There are now five employees who have tested positive since Monday, April 6. The plant was closed on Wednesday, April 8 after the company learned of the second and third cases in Brampton. "The decision to re-open the Brampton poultry plant will be made only once we are confident it is safe to do so," Maple Leaf said in a statement. "The City of Brampton has seen a significant increase in cases locally in the last week, with more than 400 cases now confirmed." The company has not said how the affected individuals are believed to have contracted the disease. In addition to these cases, an employee at the Heritage plant in Hamilton tested positive on Monday, April 6, and two from the Viau plant in Montreal tested positive on Sunday, April 12. Operations continue at the Heritage plant while the Viau plant remained closed on Monday for a deep cleaning and investigation. "At each of the three plants, we immediately implemented our COVID-19 response plans, making sure that all health, safety and sanitation measures were implemented, including notifying any coworkers who had close contact with these individuals so that they can self-quarantine for 14 days," the company stated. In addition to its safety measures, Maple Leaf has recently implemented new protocol for its employees, such as temperature screening upon arrival and mandatory face covering. Production at Brampton Chrysler plant shut down due to coronavirus concerns | BramptonGuardian.com Production at Brampton Chrysler plant shut down due to coronavirus concerns News Mar 19, 2020 by Steve Cornwell Brampton Guardian The Brampton Fiat Chrysler plant is shutting down production due to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) announced in a March 18 release that the company was ceasing production at all its North American plants due to the COVID-19 pandemic until the end of the month. Vito Beato, first vice-president of Unifor Local 1285, which represents thousands of workers at the Brampton plant, confirmed that the facility had suspended production effective March 18 because of the virus. According to a FCA fact sheet, there are 3,202 hourly employees at the facility. Beato said plants that supply parts to the Chrysler facility have also shut down due to the virus, so the number of workers affected by the shutdown is higher. He said union members will have access to employment insurance (EI) and additional benefits while the plants are closed. “We're working with the companies and the government, of course, to look at getting everybody topped up,” he said. “So we're looking to make sure that everyone makes as close to 100 per cent of their wages as possible.” In the March 18 release, FCA said they worked with the autoworkers’ union to come to the decision to cease production at their North American plants through to the end of March. The company said that while production is paused, it will work with the union to implement changes to “shift timings, structures and enhanced cleaning protocols.” In the release, FCA CEO Mike Manley said that “we need to ensure employees feel safe at work and that we are taking every step possible to protect them.” “We will continue to do what is right for our people through this period of uncertainty,” he said. Automakers Ford, General Motors (GM) and Honda have all also announced suspension of production at their North American facilities due to coronavirus concerns. GM and Ford said in separate releases that production would be halted until at least March 30. On March 18, Honda announced plans to halt production for six days, starting March 23. The Chrysler 300, Dodge Charger and Dodge Challenger are assembled at the Brampton plant, the FCA fact sheet said. GM and Ford said in separate releases that production would be halted until at least March 30. On March 18, Honda announced plans to halt production for six days, starting March 23. The Chrysler 300, Dodge Charger and Dodge Challenger are assembled at the Brampton plant, the FCA fact sheet said. Top Stories More News More News

Production at Brampton Chrysler plant shut down due to coronavirus concerns | BramptonGuardian.com Production at Brampton Chrysler plant shut down due to coronavirus concerns News Mar 19, 2020 by Steve Cornwell Brampton Guardian The Brampton Fiat Chrysler plant is shutting down production due to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) announced in a March 18 release that the company was ceasing production at all its North American plants due to the COVID-19 pandemic until the end of the month. Vito Beato, first vice-president of Unifor Local 1285, which represents thousands of workers at the Brampton plant, confirmed that the facility had suspended production effective March 18 because of the virus. According to a FCA fact sheet, there are 3,202 hourly employees at the facility. Beato said plants that supply parts to the Chrysler facility have also shut down due to the virus, so the number of workers affected by the shutdown is higher. He said union members will have access to employment insurance (EI) and additional benefits while the plants are closed. “We're working with the companies and the government, of course, to look at getting everybody topped up,” he said. “So we're looking to make sure that everyone makes as close to 100 per cent of their wages as possible.” In the March 18 release, FCA said they worked with the autoworkers’ union to come to the decision to cease production at their North American plants through to the end of March. The company said that while production is paused, it will work with the union to implement changes to “shift timings, structures and enhanced cleaning protocols.” In the release, FCA CEO Mike Manley said that “we need to ensure employees feel safe at work and that we are taking every step possible to protect them.” “We will continue to do what is right for our people through this period of uncertainty,” he said. Automakers Ford, General Motors (GM) and Honda have all also announced suspension of production at their North American facilities due to coronavirus concerns. GM and Ford said in separate releases that production would be halted until at least March 30. On March 18, Honda announced plans to halt production for six days, starting March 23. The Chrysler 300, Dodge Charger and Dodge Challenger are assembled at the Brampton plant, the FCA fact sheet said.
